summary: mutant clouds represent the first stage in the genetic and antiviral diversification of RNA viruses, such as foot and mouth disease virus (FMDV), an important animal pathogen. a FMDV microarray was designed and optimized to detect simultaneously the seven FMDV serotypes. RNA viruses replicate with mutation rates in the range of 10-3 to 10-5 substitutions per nucleotide copied [2,3]. a transmission bottleneck may result in the establishment in the recipient host of one (or few) variant(s) sampled from the mutant cloud that replicates in the infected donor. the antigenic diversity of FMDV is reflected in the occurrence of seven serotypes (A, O, C, Asia1, SAT1, SAT2, SAT3), and multiple subtypes and variants that defy classification due to the continuous recognition of mutant forms. in vaccination-challenge experiments no cross-protection is observed among representatives of a different serotype. the overlap of residues involved in receptor recognition and antibody binding implies that variations at the G-H loop of VP1 can have consequences both for the antigenic behavior of the virus and its host range. studies in cell culture have shown that FMDV can evolve towards variants with altered RGD that display a remarkable expansion of host cell tropism
